explanation: Italian articles agree with the gender and number of the noun. Use 'il' (m. sing.), 'la' (f. sing.), 'i' (m. pl.), 'le' (f. pl.). Use 'lo/gli' before s+consonant, z, ps, gn. Use 'l'' before vowels.
Use 'un' (m. sing. before consonant or vowel), 'uno' (m. sing. before s+consonant, z, etc.), 'una' (f. sing. before consonant), 'un'' (f. sing. before vowel).
Most Italian nouns ending in -o are masculine; most ending in -a are feminine. Nouns ending in -e can be either gender and must be memorised. Nouns ending in -ione are usually feminine.
Regular -are verbs drop the -are ending and add: -o, -i, -a, -iamo, -ate, -ano.
Regular -ere verbs drop the -ere ending and add: -o, -i, -e, -iamo, -ete, -ono.
Regular -ire verbs have two patterns. Type 1: -o, -i, -e, -iamo, -ite, -ono. Type 2 (with -isc-): -isco, -isci, -isce, -iamo, -ite, -iscono.
examples: dormire (type 1) → io dormo, tu dormi, lui dorme
finire (type 2) → io finisco, tu finisci, lui finisce

explanation: Used for completed past actions. Formed with: avere/essere (present) + past participle. Most verbs use avere. Verbs of motion/state often use essere (and the participle agrees with subject gender/number).
examples: Ho mangiato la pizza. (I ate the pizza — avere)
Sono andato al mercato. (I went to the market — essere, m.)
Siamo andati al mare. (We went to the sea — essere, m. pl.)

explanation: Adjectives agree with the noun in gender and number. -o/-a adjectives have 4 forms. -e adjectives have only 2 forms (sing./pl.).
examples: un gatto nero / una casa nera (m./f. sing.)
un fiore verde / una mela verde (m./f. sing. — -e type)
fiori verdi / mele verdi (m./f. pl. — -e type)

explanation: To negate a sentence, place 'non' before the verb. Double negatives are standard in Italian (non...niente, non...mai, non...nessuno).
examples: Non parlo francese. (I don't speak French.)
Non mangio mai la carne. (I never eat meat.)
Non ho visto nessuno. (I didn't see anyone.)

explanation: Italian subject pronouns are often omitted because the verb ending identifies the subject. Use them for emphasis or clarity.
examples: Lei (you, formal), noi (we), voi (you pl.), loro (they)
Parli italiano? (Do you speak Italian? — pronoun omitted)
Io parlo italiano, tu no. (I speak Italian, you don't — emphasis)
